articles.author: Nick Thieme
articles.description:
The most widely used technique for finding the largest or smallest values of a math function turns out to be a fundamentally difficult computational problem.            
The post Computer Scientists Discover Limits of Major Research Algorithm first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Computer Scientists Discover Limits of Major Research Algorithm

articles.author: Viviane Callier
articles.description:
The evolution of a defensive gland in beetles shows how organs can arise from novel cells carving out new functional niches for their neighbors.            
The post How Do New Organs Evolve? A Beetle Gland Shows the Way. first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: How Do New Organs Evolve? A Beetle Gland Shows the Way.

articles.author: Karmela Padavic-Callaghan
articles.description:
The unambiguous discovery of a Wigner crystal relied on a novel technique for probing the insides of complex materials.             
The post Physicists Create a Bizarre ‘Wigner Crystal’ Made Purely of Electrons first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Physicists Create a Bizarre ‘Wigner Crystal’ Made Purely of Electrons

articles.author: Steve Nadis
articles.description:
A pair of researchers has shown that trying to classify groups of numbers called “torsion-free abelian groups” is as hard as it can possibly be.            
The post Mathematicians Solve Decades-Old Classification Problem first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Mathematicians Solve Decades-Old Classification Problem

articles.author: Jonathan O'Callaghan
articles.description:
Brown dwarfs such as “The Accident” are illuminating the murky borderlands that separate planets from stars.            
The post Neither Star nor Planet: A Strange Brown Dwarf Puzzles Astronomers first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Neither Star nor Planet: A Strange Brown Dwarf Puzzles Astronomers

articles.author: Allison Whitten
articles.description:
By focusing on relationships between solutions to polynomial equations, rather than the exact solutions themselves, Évariste Galois changed the course of modern mathematics.            
The post Galois Groups and the Symmetries of Polynomials first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Galois Groups and the Symmetries of Polynomials

articles.author: Jake Buehler
articles.description:
Showy male competitions over mating privileges have grabbed scientists’ attention more often, but new work hints that sexual selection is also widespread among females.            
The post Mating Contests Among Females, Long Ignored, May Shape Evolution first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Mating Contests Among Females, Long Ignored, May Shape Evolution

articles.description:
Guten Tag, friends! 👋

If you're subscribed to this newsletter for a while, you know that I discovered the electro piano duo Grandbrothers and became a big fan. I saw them live this week, and I'm so happy; live music is just the best!
Before jumping into nerdy stuff, let's start the week with some doggo cuteness.


          
            
This week's Web Weekly includes:
Fancy CSS features: accent-color, font-family: system-ui and color-scheme
workplace privileges
directory-dependent git configuration
... and, as always, GitHub repositories, a new Tiny Helper and some music.
Ready? Steady. Go!
How Google generates search result titles





          
            
Google changed the way how they generate the search result titles and now consider h1 elements, too. It's a good reminder about…
articles.title: Web Weekly #34 (#blogPost)

articles.description:
I just came across Marcus Crane's post Conditionally setting your gitconfig. Marcus explains how to use conditional includes and apply directory dependent git configuration.
Here's an example from his blog post:
[user]
  email = user@example.com
  name = User
  signingkey = ABC123
[commit]
  gpgSign = true
[includeIf "gitdir:~/work/"]
  path = ~/.work.gitconfig

The git docs describe that you include configs depending on branch name, too.
I don't need different git configurations these days, but it's good to know this feature exists. 👏


          
          
            Reply to Stefan
articles.title: How to apply directory dependent git configuration using conditional imports (#tilPost)
Promises-based timer functions are supported in Node.js 16 (#snippet)

articles.description:
There's been some buzz about Safari (and its "quirks") lately. In its latest round, the webdev community discovered that Webkit (the engine powering Safari) supports the new and fancy AVIF image format, but Safari does not. Outrageous – how can that be?
If you want to learn more about AVIF, Jake Archibald has you covered. 😉
I haven't played much with the new image format yet, but it's supposed to lead to smaller files than webp and jpeg. That's great news – a faster web is a better web. You can use the picture element, let the browser load the best and newest image format, and call it a day. Win-win!
But Apple decided not to ship AVIF in Safari because the image format is not supported in their operating systems yet.
Why would one disable features that make websites faster?

Apple product…
articles.title: Safari only supports image formats macOS/iOS support, and that's good for some users (#note)

articles.description:
I just added a new CLI tool to my dotfiles, and I think you're going to love it.
Many people use ctrl + r (reverse search) to navigate and search their shell history. I never liked this shell functionality because it's very barebones and not intuitive. McFly replaces this command and makes finding past commands a breeze!
Here's how it looks like! 👇

articles.description:
Hei, party people!

I was at an open-air concert this weekend. The show was so-so (for the Germans: it was a weird mix of Thees Uhlmann, Marcus Wiebusch and Bosse), but let me tell you, I do miss live music! I hope you had a good week yourself!
Before we jump into web stuff, let's start the week with some cuteness overload. 😆

Avif support is coming to Firefox




          
            
Quick heads-up: Avif support is coming to Firefox. 🎉 It's only a matter of time now until Edge joins the party (and who knows when Safari follows). Neverthele…
articles.title: Web Weekly #32 (#blogPost)

articles.description:
Dobré Ráno, party people!

I'm a little late with this newsletter this week because I spent my weekend on a boat, in a beer garden and in a Karaoke bar. And all that led to a very slow Sunday. 🙈
Other than that, I'm participating in leadership coaching right now, and last week I learned about a new approach to decision-making. My coach and I discussed three ways/lenses to look at conflicts, decisions and the world.
The reverse lens: “What would the other person in this conflict say?"
The long lens: "How will I look at this problem in six months?"
The wide lens: "How can I learn and grow from the situation?"
I really like this approach of considering "the bigger picture" and will try to use it going forward. Let's make less hot-headed and short-sighted decisions!
Before we jump into web st…
articles.title: Web Weekly #31 (#blogPost)
Can we have custom media queries, please? (#note)
